body: @mbien thanks for the review. Indeed I rebased multiple times and it seems something got messed up. I'll leave it as is, as even in worst case a unittestset is executed twice on GH.

Context: This happens when I call for code completion in "Evaluate expression", which is now broken.

@mbien FYI

@mbien, why do you think the _commits needs squashing_? I see:
- [Initial position of breakpoints is next to navigator](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7496/commits/18db1f1c186a9d32176ad94c881f58393c21df86)
- [Put Evaluate Expression between debugger view and breakpoints](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7496/commits/98f14f8d2c3b98ad10c275dd34886af8aa5f126f)
- [Make sure evaluatorPane is opened when debugging starts](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7496/commits/14fcf6990630ef2a1c5d25bc6e132a0eadb65ce1)
- [Moving the navigator definition below other ones](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7496/commits/9b461e13359e599cbb607e06f1ee5198f195b55b)

Maybe the forth one is slightly unnecessary, but the _first three clearly describe_ what's the intention of the change. I prefer to keep them - e.g. merge, not squash.

`NullPointerException` is caused by JSON attribute "VirtualSize" loaded in [DockerAction.getImages()#153](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/ide/docker.api/src/org/netbeans/modules/docker/api/DockerAction.java#L153).

The attribute ["VirtualSize" was removed in API v1.44](https://github.com/moby/moby/pull/45469) for endpoints `GET /images/json` and `GET /images/{id}/json` that is used in [DockerAction.getImages()#144](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/ide/docker.api/src/org/netbeans/modules/docker/api/DockerAction.java#L144).

[Docker Engine 25.0 release notes](https://docs.docker.com/engine/release-notes/25.0/#removed)

![Screenshot 2024-06-30 at 12-24-33 Docker Engine 25 0 release notes Docker Docs](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/12944221/6850aed2-68ec-4e4f-bdcd-6d03efb11221)

@jtulach well, the original intention why we allowed multiple commits per PR was to not discourage cleanups in bugfix PRs for example. One commit could refactor, the other fix the bug/add a feature without obfuscating what is happening. (main reason why I advocated for the option of multi commit PRs at least)

But simple PRs like here can be described by a few bullet points in the commit msg and everyone can still see what is happening while looking at the diff.

Many projects don't allow merges at all, they auto squash+rebase on "merge" (which also leads to an easy to understand history). The reason we decided to disable that one is because there were some problems with author headers in past. If the git account isn't properly setup mails can disappear etc. (I forgot the details but there were problems when author != committer in some circumstances). Sometimes too much choice is also bad. We had accidental merges where someone thought that squash was selected and the whole dev cycle got merged. Now there is only merge, so the last step of the review is to make sure the PR is properly squashed and that there are no surprises in the [commit header](https://patch-diff.githubusercontent.com/raw/apache/netbeans/pull/7496.patch). Keep it simple works often best.

Having multiple commits per PR can also cause problems during git bisect, since extra care is needed to make sure each individual commit builds and tests.

so in short: the thought is that most PRs can be one commit, but it can be useful to allow multiple for large PRs or special situations, e.g having commits from different authors in the same PR etc.

I try to follow the same rule of course: the last item I worked on ended up being 4 commits, split into 3 PRs: https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7512, https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7515, https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7513 (I almost made that 3 commits though)

edit: also PRs _are_ the release notes. So having multiple completely different things in one PR can also lead to problems.

NetBeans never preferred squashing over merges while I was actively around. 

> Many projects don't allow merges at all, they auto squash+rebase on "merge"

However NetBeans isn't one of such projects and I hope it will never be.

> simple PRs like here

This is not a simple PR! It was when I only proposed to change:

- [Initial position of breakpoints is next to navigator](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7496/commits/18db1f1c186a9d32176ad94c881f58393c21df86)

but then you asked me to do additional (and unrelated) change repositioning the _evaluate expression_ view:

- [Put Evaluate Expression between debugger view and breakpoints](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7496/commits/98f14f8d2c3b98ad10c275dd34886af8aa5f126f)

and yet another to open _evaluate expression view_ when debugging starts:

- [Make sure evaluatorPane is opened when debugging starts](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7496/commits/14fcf6990630ef2a1c5d25bc6e132a0eadb65ce1)


Those are three different changes and I refuse to squash them. Can you remove your _needs squashing_ label? If not, and there really is a policy we have to squash commits (link please), then tell me how can I proceed without squashing? Shall I drop the evaluate expression changes from this PR and integrate only [Initial position of breakpoints is next to navigator](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7496/commits/18db1f1c186a9d32176ad94c881f58393c21df86) and leave the rest for some other PRs?
That's right: this is the correct change

> Shall I drop the evaluate expression changes from this PR and integrate only [Initial position of breakpoints is next to navigator](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7496/commits/18db1f1c186a9d32176ad94c881f58393c21df86) and leave the rest for some other PRs?

here is how I would integrate a change like this:

example 1:
 - rename this PR to "Update breakpoints window position and always open expression evaluator" (or something similar which mentions both user facing changes)
 - merge with 2 commits, one per feature
 
example 2:
 - rename as in 1
 - merge as 1 commit
 
example 3:
 - keep title
 - merge breakpoint window changes as 1 commit
 - move rest to other PR

I think all examples above would generate good results when read from the release notes and also from git history. In the example given previously in https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7496#issuecomment-2197416124, i opted for 3 since it became a larger change, so i made it 3 PRs. But this diff is easy to parse, so example 2 or 1 would be completely fine IMO.

> but then you asked me to do additional (and unrelated) change repositioning the evaluate expression view:

I promise I won't do this again. But my intention was to not _ask_ you to do anything. I only mentioned that I had something on my todo list which slightly overlaps with this change, please read my initial post https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7496#issuecomment-2179552776. Once you implemented the expression eval window positioning, I tested it and mentioned that it did not open. (that was also when I noticed https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7528 and that the "Reset Windows" feature does not work as expected).

> If Jakarta EE 10 API Library has already been added the imported packages are the correct ones: *jakarta.persistence. **, otherwise they are *javax.persistence. ** and lots of errors are reported."

Yes. We can discuss whether missing libraries should default to jakarta or javax namespace, but in any case we need to guess. So from my POV: Works as expected.

> Works as expected.

Don't think it is a good idea to automatically generate code which is marked all red.

> 2. "How to reproduce" means: What are the exact steps, starting from a clean NetBeans installation to reproduce the issue

Create an entity class with "**Entity classes from database**" wizard
After that cerate jsf pages, controllers and what else is needed with "**JSF pages from entity classes**" wizard

According to me nobody has checked these wizards since their first release years ago and after the transitions from javax to jakarta, they generate wrong code. 

Here is my netbeans project
[wizard2.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16042204/wizard2.zip)

I just generated a maven web application with the JakartaEE 10 selected. Then I did what you said and get a cleanly generated code. This was also done when the code templates for support of the jakarta namespace was added.

> According to me nobody has checked these wizards since their first release years ago and after the transitions from javax to jakarta, they generate wrong code.

I strongly suggest, that you keep such accusations to yourself.

You claim that this generated code:

```html
<h:commandLink action="#{badgeController.next}"
```

is invalid. On what do you base that? Reading this:

https://jakarta.ee/learn/docs/jakartaee-tutorial/current/web/faces-el/faces-el.html#_parameterized_method_calls

It explicitly gives this sample:

```html
<h:commandButton action="#{trader.buy}" value="buy"/>
```

You can argue, that method references should always be generated with parantheses, but apparently they are not required.

I validated that with a trivial JSF page on Glassfish 7.0.11.
What remains for me is, that the JSF Controller seems to generate JSF `ManagedBeans` and not CDI beans in the ant project.

> _Note:_ If we already did something similar in #5294, then it is unfortunate, as I explained above. Ideally, we should revert the API change and follow the steps I described.

By similarity to #5294, I was referring to the purpose of that PR.
If I understood it correctly, there were no changes to the public api in that PR.

> ah I get it. COS stands for compile on save. 

Ah, I hadn't realised that the meaning of COS there was your stumbling point or I'd have mentioned it. 😄  Hopefully can be separated out from this change, and possibly a discussion to be had elsewhere on whether this slowly deteriorating feature should just be removed?!

> Hopefully can be separated out from this change,

What do you mean by that? All this does is to switch from component.xml to annotations. I think it would be more confusing/error prone when IDEWorkspaceReader1/2 would keep using component.xml while the NbEventSpy is using annotations and both are built in the same module.

Sorry, badly worded. I just meant separating out the discussion on the other points you raised - whether it's actually working correctly, whether it needs fixing now or for Maven 4. As you said, this PR should not affect things there (or make it any worse!).
@neilcsmith-net awesome. Yep agreed. Btw I updated https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7529#issuecomment-2198498169 with a test case since I discovered that cos does work, just extremely delayed.

>> I strongly suggest, that you keep such accusations to yourself.

Keep in mind that English is not my first language, I'm sorry if what I wrote may sound rude or impolite.

I wanted to try the maven project way as suggested above to verify the results, but I'm completely stuck.
If I use latest Payara server, 6.2024.6,  I cannot even add jsf framework. 
 
![Cannot add jsf](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/assets/49644267/28935666-f377-4725-bfa5-e37dc24d6685)

Cannot select anything in that dialog window. Don't know if it is a Payara problem.

I then installed latest Glassfish, I can add jsf framework, but I'm not familiar with maven project and finally I cannot deploy due to a persistence unit problem. In fact there is no **@PersistenceContext(unitName = "myPU")** annotation and I don't know how to tell the name of the Persistence unit.
Probably I will have no time for further investigation, I tried my best, I wrote this bug report to improve Netbeans, but due to my limited knowledge I cannot give much help.

I finally found the **@PersistenceUnit** annotation, I was looking in the wrong class. 
Application is correctly deployed but when I click the first link to list all items I get the same error:
`The class 'm2.mavenw2.BadgeController' does not have the property 'previous'.`
So generated code doesn't work in Glassfish 7.0.15 too.

In my first post I forgot another problem I saw.
In the generated  index.xhtml the namespace is:
`xmlns:h="jakarta.faces.html"`
and Glassfish correctly renders it as a jsf page.
In all the other generated classes, such as List.xhtml, the namespace is:
`xmlns:h="jakarta.faces/jsf/html"`
and Glassfish renders it as plain html.

**UPDATE**
After changing the namespaces to the form:
`xmlns:h="jakarta.faces.html"`
methods can be called without parantheses.
Ok, a bit surprising, that `.class` files are handled by `JavaNode`, but the fix looks straight forward, so my positive review still stands.

Yes, can reproduce.  Seems to be OK for method and method parameter annotations, but not on the return type.  That definitely seems to be a bug.  Then there's an open question about what the default should be.

@neilcsmith-net @Chris2011 Hello! Not sure if this is the right place to put feedback. If needed I can create a separate issue for it but for now I'll go ahead and comment here.

I really don't think this is a good idea, in principle. First, if I'm not mistaken there already is a "welcome" dashboard which serves this very purpose.

Second, an empty editor view is _supposed_ to be empty. When all documents are closed there should be no content displayed on the editor pane, imo.

Third, based on the #7171 implementation there seems to be no way to turn this off. At least with the welcome dashboard you are able to disable it once you are familiar with the interface. But now even if you hide the dashboard you still see this which is super-distracting. It makes it seem as if something is still open even if everything is closed.

These actions and the dashboard have different purposes.  And there is no reason that because all editors are closed, there should be a massive bit of dead space in the middle of the IDE.  There is no "supposed to be" here!

The implementation was added with the ability to customize, but no UI to do so.

Close NetBeans.  Find your userdir, add a folder at `config/Windows2/`.  Inside that add an empty file with the filename `Background_hidden`. Restart NetBeans.  Problem solved!

A PR to add a UI to customize the images and actions would be considered positively.  It's not on my own immediate radar, but the implementation deliberately allows for it.  Feel free too to add a feature request issue for it.

Same behavior with JBoss EAP **6.4.22** (NetBeans 22, JDK 17). You can add JBoss as WildFly and it'll start just fine but you can't interact with it (deploy a .war, stop it, etc.) because NetBeans doesn't recognize it as started. You can stop it by closing NetBeans, though.

Last time I know for sure it worked well was on NetBeans 8.2, before the Apache NetBeans era. I have tested NetBeans 13 too and it behaves the same as NetBeans 22. Not sure if it ever worked on other versions.

@neilcsmith-net Thanks for the off-switch. It works. I appreciate it.

I guess this is a matter of opinion. In my opinion empty space in editor pane signifies that no documents are open. The emptiness by itself has a function and some users (like me) rely on it to convey the information that nothing is open. Empty space doesn't automatically mean "dead space".

If you put some content in a place where a document is supposed to be you indicate that a document is open - without giving the user an option to close it (which for me personally is frustrating). And that something grabs user's attention away from the rest of the UI like the project tree or the file tree. Besides, this only shows a huge icon and a list of actions that are already available on the toolbar - a standard location.

This is a pretty major UI change and in general I don't find it a very good practice to make changes for users without asking if they are interested, and worse, not giving them an (easy) option to say no.

(Please don't take this personally. I know it's not a nice feedback to ask an author how to turn their feature off. I don't mean to be ungrateful, especially on an os project where people put in their own time. I just disagree with the design decision and want to share my pov. I'll try and do the PR if time allows.)

Ideally would have a link to `Edit Project Goals` that opens the right section of the project properties, between the `Other Goals...` and `Edit Global Goals...` links.  Possibly another separator between `Other Goals...` and the edit actions to emphasize execution vs edit?

@tkyjovsk It is not really an empty editor, it is an empty editor background. So if you would have an empty edtor, you would have a plain file with nothing inside, a tab, line numbers, etc. It is just the place where the editor is supposed to be, when you ot move it around.

Why should not use empty space where we have it? Yes, I can understand and for those who don't want it, we should make an option for this. For this you can create a new ticket or a discussion for that. If you open NetBeans for the very first time as far as I can remember, you see the welcome page and if you close it, you see nothing. So how do you know where to start? What to do? You also don't know what an editor is maybe. It is just a "quick tutorial".

The toolbar is a different thing for users which uses mouse or navigate via tab. Do you know which keyboard shortcut is behind the action if you are new to the IDE? probably not. Different things for different use cases.

But again let's talk about in a discussion instead of this here.
+10h, no comments -> merging

For the code generation issues, this PR should help: #7539. A dev build is available from the checks page of the PR or directly:  https://github.com/apache/netbeans/suites/25564462784/artifacts/1661001646.
reducing CI to the failed jobs

This will fail. The class `org.netbeans.modules.docker.api.DockerImage` is part of the API of the module and thus removing `getVirtualSize` is an incompatbile change. The API is "friend only" (only explicitly listed other modules can access it), but still an API.

From my understanding "Virtual Size" never made sense for images, just for containers, as the image are the readonly portion and only a running container has a writable part.

So wouldn't it make sense to use `getOrDefault` also for virtual size and use the value from `Size` as fallback? On my admittingly small setup, this seems to be truthy.

I only took a quick look at this yesterday but the API seemed to be only exported to 
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/7216834b1fab41232665b9e32c2b862b658c860e/ide/docker.api/nbproject/project.xml#L130-L133
so its essentially internal since I don't think it can leak out of [docker.ui](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/7216834b1fab41232665b9e32c2b862b658c860e/ide/docker.ui/nbproject/project.xml). Not saying that we should remove it but I don't think there is anything preventing removal.

> * rename this PR to "Update breakpoints window position and always open expression evaluator"
> * merge with 2 commits, one per feature

Renamed and force-pushed as:

- [Initial position of breakpoints view is next to navigator](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7496/commits/371383fe43c119ab9bfbe54024a26c35b0f66f4e)
- [Always open expression evaluator view](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7496/commits/66953b84c3236221dd7ebe9d9f7f0d1705f4cc68)

> only mentioned that I had something on my todo list which slightly overlaps with this change

That's OK. I am glad I got your support and testing and the original PR vision got improved.

the experiment at https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/7538 showed that removal of downloader/* is likely the quickest option. It builds, it tests and I also generated an .exe installer and tested it manually (only on JDK 22 since the (native) installer can't parse ea java versions, but this is off topic).

NBI is in bad shape, unmaintained and NB is slowly transitioning to @neilcsmith-net's nbpackage, everything except windows is using it already. The NBI issue is preventing us from building or testing NetBeans on JDK 23 which is a problem.

I will open a proper PR soon, with the cleaned up changes which remove the online functionality from NBI to give it a small life time extension. This would go in first, then we can merge the nb-javac 23 PR once ready, then the CI-on-23 PR and we are (hopefully) good for the NB 23 cycle.

Also seeing consistently in Netbeans 22.  I have been unsuccessful creating a simple project that exhibits the issue.  My current project is a multi-module maven project with about 24 modules.  In the log it references a .dump file, but it has the source of a file that caused an issue this time.  It's not always the same file though.  Is there a way to send that securely somehow?

it seems the side effect of this issue includes the inability to get context-sensitive help for variables/classes as well as the inability to debug specific methods or set breakpoints.  It doesn't think the class/method is a valid test nor does it think the breakpoint is in a valid location.  The 'Navigate' context menu functionality such as "Go to Source..." or "Go to Implementation..." also does not function in this state.  If I manage to get the debugger running and it stops on a breakpoint, it shows the value of all variables as 'null'.  This is maddening.  Going to upgrade to Netbeans 23 shortly and try it.

[messages.log](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/16086927/messages.log)

For me doing a compatible change is just easier. API breakage should always raise concerns and be treated with respect. It also requires bumping major version of the affected module, updating the using module and raising the specification version of that module. It is just messy.

"friend only" dependencies are APIs being stabilized. If you don't want an API, you can use an implementation dependency in the IDE and be done with it.

Not sure what is the intention of this issue. There is no need for an issue to get things into NetBeans. The normal process is to prepare a PR for the feature you want to implement, get it reviewed (might involve multiple cycles) and then get a committer to actually merge it to master.

It helps (from my perspective) if the PR is focused and changes things incrementally. I.e. finding someone to review a PR that changes the whole way PHP is handled in the IDE will be impossible, finding someone, who reviews a PR, that fixes a specific issue and validates that with tests is much more likely.

From my perspective the two primary contacts for PHP development in the IDE are @junichi11 and @tmysik and it would be good if they could chime in.

Totally agree with @matthiasblaesing, creating a PR (or perhaps better, more smaller PRs, if possible?) would be great. Definitely ask for review from @junichi11, I can try to help too.

Thank you.

@eirikbakke @sdedic any updates on this?

@haidubogdan the general answer is:

1. You create a personal fork of the NetBeans repository
2. You create a new branch from current master to work on your feature
3. You create a PR from that branch

If your changes can be integrated independently, steps 2+3 can be done multiple times in parallel. If they build on top of each other, you can create new branches based on the PR branch for next step. However you should be prepared to rebase that work onto the finally reviewed PR branch. While a PR is in review there is a quite big chance, that changes will have to be done as part of that.

This was my first reaction and as @mbien writes in #7542 also his. But this needs someone to actually do the work and I decided for myself that I'm not willing to do it.

I had read an explanation about the [difference between "Size" and "VirtualSize"](https://github.com/docker/docs/issues/1520#issuecomment-305179362) in the docker repository itself. From the explanation, it seems to me that `"Size"` and `"VirtualSize"` are different. However, listing the images using a version of the engine (I tested `v1.24` which is in the engine documentation and `v1.43` which is the last version where the "VirtualSize" attribute was still there) in which the `"VirtualSize"` attribute was still there, the value for `"Size"` and `"VirtualSize"` are the same. Thanks for your help.

I found this error after my pc ran out of battery and the drive where I had NetBeans got disconnected. Seems like the cache got corrupted, because deleting NetBeans' cache and restarting it fixed the problem
Made the suggested corrections.

NB disables a few features if mvnd is run in parallel mode (e.g you see it on the folding bar in the output too), this is intended. 

You should see that button again if you run mvnd in sequential mode, e.g by setting `-T 1`.

Thanks!  Think that works and a good change for NB23.

We could perhaps (in future!) standardize some of the terminology here.  We use Goals and Actions in different places, and neither entirely overlaps with Maven's concept of Goal.
You are right with `-T 1` it works. It would be mentioned somewhere.

we would probably have to call it "action" everywhere to be technically correct, since `compile` is a phase and `compile:compile` a goal which happens to be in that phase. The action presets work for both, phases and goals.

Its just that goal is the more familiar term most likely, so if it happens to support phases it is probably ok to call the menu entry point "Edit Goals..."?

I would probably leave it as is for now tbh but I would also have no problem to change it to "Edit Actions...".
